openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Andorra is characterized as a developed, free market economy primarily driven by the sectors of finance, retail, and tourism.
• In 2024, Andorra's gross domestic product (GDP) was approximately US$6.00 billion.
• The country is an attractive destination for shoppers from France and Spain, functioning as a free port that facilitates duty-free shopping.
• Andorra has developed extensive summer and winter tourist resorts, supporting its tourism industry.
• The country hosts around 270 hotels and 400 restaurants, along with numerous shops, indicating a robust tourist infrastructure.
• Tourism employs a growing segment of the domestic labor force, with an estimated 10 million tourists visiting annually.
• There is an active trade in consumer goods, including imported manufactured items, which are less expensive due to duty-free status, making them more affordable than in neighboring countries.
• Andorra's duty-free status has significantly influenced its relationship with the European Union (EU), sparking controversy and negotiations.
• Negotiations regarding duty-free status and the broader relationship with the EU began in 1987, shortly after Spain joined the EU.
• An agreement effective from July 1991 established duty-free quotas and imposed limits on certain items, notably milk products, tobacco, and alcoholic beverages.
• Under this agreement, Andorra is allowed to maintain price differences from other EU countries, and visitors are granted limited duty-free allowances.
• Electoral results in Andorra suggest that many citizens support government reform initiatives and believe that some degree of EU integration is necessary to sustain economic prosperity.
• Arable land accounts for less than 2% of Andorra's territory; historically, agriculture was the mainstay of the economy until tourism surged.
• Sheep raising has been the principal agricultural activity, while tobacco cultivation is considered lucrative.
• Most of Andorra's food supplies are imported, reflecting limited domestic agricultural production.
• The country’s manufacturing sector includes the production of cigars, cigarettes, and furniture, serving both domestic consumption and export markets.
• A hydroelectric plant located at Les Escaldes, with a capacity of 26.5 megawatts, supplies approximately 40% of Andorra's electricity needs; the remaining electricity is supplied by Spain.
• Tourism is the primary sector of Andorra's economy, accounting for approximately 80% of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• Annually, an estimated 9 million tourists visit Andorra, attracted by its duty-free status and its summer and winter resort facilities.

• The country's comparative economic advantage has diminished recently due to the opening of neighboring France and Spain's economies, which has increased the availability of goods and reduced tariffs.
• The banking sector in Andorra is significant to the economy, benefiting from the country's "tax haven" status, which attracts financial activities and services.
• Agricultural production in Andorra is limited primarily due to a scarcity of arable land, necessitating the importation of most food supplies.
• The main livestock activity in Andorra is sheep raising.
• Manufacturing industries in Andorra mainly produce cigarettes, cigars, and furniture.
• Andorra is a member of the European Union (EU) Customs Union and is treated as an EU member for trade purposes concerning manufactured goods, allowing it to trade without tariffs.
• The Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of Andorra based on purchasing power parity was US$3.327 billion in 2015, ranking 190th in the world.
• The estimated real GDP growth rate for 2015 was 8.95%, placing Andorra at 132nd globally.
• The GDP per capita, adjusted for purchasing power parity, was US$49,900 in 2015, making it the 29th highest in the world.
• The sectoral composition of GDP in 2015 was: agriculture at 11.9%, industry at 33.6%, and services at 54.5%.
• Data on the population below the poverty line is not available (N/A).
• Household income or consumption data by percentage share for the lowest and highest 10% is not available (N/A).
• The inflation rate for consumer prices in 2015 was -0.9%, ranking 225th worldwide.
• The labor force numbered 42,230 in 2007, ranking 185th globally.
• Employment by occupation in 2007 was approximately 0.3% in agriculture, 20.8% in industry, and 79% in services.
• The unemployment rate was 3.7%, placing Andorra at 183rd in the world.
• The government’s budget revenues were US$1.872 billion, while expenditures were US$2.06 billion in 2016.
• Major industries include tourism (notably skiing), banking, timber, and furniture manufacturing.
• The industrial production growth rate was -3.9% in 2020, ranking 184th worldwide.

• Electricity production data is not available; however, electricity is generated primarily through hydro sources (40%) and other sources (60%) imported from Spain, with no fossil fuel or nuclear contribution.
• Andorra imports all its electricity, mainly from Spain and France, and generates a small amount of hydropower domestically.
• Agricultural products include small quantities of rye, wheat, barley, oats, vegetables, tobacco, sheep, and cattle.
• The value of exports was US$1.842 billion in 2020, ranking 163rd globally.
• Export commodities include integrated circuits, dental fitting supplies, cars, gold, and essential oils (2021).
• Major export partners are Spain (40%), France (19%), the United States (11%), and Mauritania (5%) as of 2019.
• Imports totaled US$1.727 billion in 2020, ranking 178th worldwide.
• Import commodities include cars, refined petroleum, perfumes, shaving products, and liquors (2019).
• Main import partners are Spain (71%) and France (17%) as of 2019.
• External debt was zero dollars in 2016.
• Andorra does not receive any economic aid.
• The official currency is the Euro, which has replaced the French franc and Spanish peseta.
• Exchange rates fluctuated over the years, with the Euro per US dollar being 0.845 in 2021, 0.6827 in 2008, 0.7306 in 2007, and other values from 2002 to 2006.
• The fiscal year follows the calendar year.
• In 2022, the sector with the highest number of registered companies in Andorra was Services, accounting for 2,515 companies.
• The Retail Trade sector had the second-highest number of registered companies, totaling 1,157.
• The Wholesale Trade sector ranked third in terms of registered companies, with a total of 1,144.
